ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed skills in reading research papers and analyzing the impact of money in politics.

- got to read seminal papers on money in politics and examine how power operates through monetary influence on all aspects of policymaking
- learned how to analyze academic papers 
- honed research skills (and refreshed my r skills)
Deep dive into various facets of American politics in which money has influence, including lobbying, campaign finance, and occupational background of legislators

Insight into the political science research around money in American politics, opening for new research in the future, and the impact of Citizens United. Also, experience engaging in our own political science research project in a chosen area (and working with data from the FEC, Follow the Money/Open Secrets, and other platforms).
I learned a lot about the different manifestations of money and how it exerts influence in politics. I learned how to conduct research and evaluate political science research

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very strong participation aspect, the guests were also a great addition. Weakness- some weeks felt a little dry as we were just discussing papers. Perhaps there could be a way to improve student engagement, maybe space out the presentations so they are through the semester instead of the last few weeks of material?

strengths
- good selection of readings
- great discussions and engagement from prof

weaknesses
- sometimes reading load was a bit much
- would have loved more space to discuss projects in class
- would have liked to turn focus toward papers earlier on in course (maybe replace response papers with project proposals and early writing drafts, e.g. lit review)

Strengths: Professor Hacker is the number one strength of the this course. He is genuinely one of the most intelligent and engaging professors I have ever had and makes every lecture interesting. His curation of readings were amazing and he was very responsive to the critiques we had of any paper. This is one of the only classes where it felt like we really critically read every research paper and it felt like we were true political scientists!

Weaknesses: Lots of reading and the 2 hour seminar can sometimes go by very slowly at times. Final project also could've been started a bit earlier

This was a great course! Undoubtedly, one of the greatest strengths is Professor Hacker's knowledge and engagement with the field. He had so much to add in each conversation and brought in a great slate of other political scientists to discuss their research with the course. The course was well organized and offered opportunities for engagement. I think the course could be improved by revamping the response papers -- I would have rather done a shorter, weekly discussion post that everyone had to do each week than the 3 or 4 response papers. I enjoyed reading my classmate's insights and it would have been nice to streamline that and offer some more time for us to read them before class.

Strengths: great Professor, you learn about a wide range of topics, the chance to conduct your own research
Weaknesses: more benchmarks for the final project earlier in the semester

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would. Professor hacker and Sam did a great job teaching this course and I learned a lot.
yes! incredible prof and incredible class! reading load can be a lot at times but its so worth it!

Would highly recommend. It was genuinely the best course I have taken at Yale and I learned so much about political science in general, along with research methodology. The workload was high but not extremely intense and the payoff is amazing.

Yes! Any student who has taken Professor Hacker's other course knows how plugged in he is with political science research and happenings in the field. It was especially interesting to take this course preceding an election year, and I'm sure it will only improve in the future. This was a great seminar and I really enjoyed the syllabus and the application to the final project at the end of the course.
Yes if you're interested in the subject you should definitely take it! You're very supported throughout the course.
